issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires the Farm to hold its animals in a List and instructs to "Initialize the ArrayList in a constructor with no arguments." (UML and Part 3 text). The solution implementation instead uses a Set (HashSet) for the animals attribute and corresponding getter/setter signatures (Set<Animal>). This is a structural mismatch: tests or student expectations that rely on a List/ArrayList (including ordering and the specified collection type) will not match the solution's use of Set, and the solution does not follow the specific construction instruction in the problem statement.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the collection type consistent with the problem statement. Update the solution (and any tests) so Farm stores animals in a List<Animal> and initializes it as an ArrayList in the no-arg constructor. Concretely: change the field to 'private List<Animal> animals;', import java.util.ArrayList and java.util.List, initialize 'this.animals = new ArrayList<>();', and adjust getter/setter signatures to use List<Animal>. Alternatively, if using a Set was intentional, update the problem text and UML to specify Set/HashSet and remove the ArrayList requirement so the specification matches the implementation.

issues.description: The UML / problem statement explicitly specifies the Farm aggregation as 'animals: List<Animal>' and instructs students to initialize it as an ArrayList in a no-argument constructor. The reference solution instead declares the collection as 'Set<Animal> animals' and initializes it with a HashSet. This is a semantic mismatch of the same conceptual entity (the farm's animal collection) across artifacts: the problem expects a List/ArrayList while the solution provides a Set/HashSet. Students may be confused about which collection type to use (ordering and duplicate behaviour differ), and tests or grading checks that assume an ArrayList/List would fail or mislead students implementing according to the instructions.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem statement: change the Farm field and its accessor signatures to use List<Animal> (not Set), and initialize it with new ArrayList<>() in the no-argument constructor. Alternatively, if use of a Set was intentional, update the problem statement and UML to specify Set/HashSet so all artifacts agree.
